Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Quantitative analysis of brain clock oscillations and associated cellular contacts and morphologies
Award.AbstractNarration:
The suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) of the mammalian brain is a master daily clock, controlling the timing of virtually all bodily functions, including sleep/wake cycles, hormonal secretions and locomotor activity. It is now possible to determine how well the clock is working, by simultaneously measuring timing in individual genes, cells, whole SCN tissue and behavior. How the ~20,000 individual SCN "clock" cells are organized in time and space to serve as a reliable clock that directs the timing of activities throughout the body is the experimental focus of the work. This problem will be addressed using new molecular tools, animals with mutations in clock genes, bioluminescent cells that continuously signal the expression of clock genes, along with high powered computer analyses of tremendous amounts of data: These tools enable simultaneous monitoring of gene and protein production in many cells, in large tissue volumes, and over time scales of minutes, hours and days, and will reveal how daily time is coded in this system.

The results will reveal how the workings of individual neurons converge to produce a circadian brain clock, and to show how the brain compensates in the face of disruptions (such as defective genes or proteins). Women and minority undergraduates (generally underrepresented in computer sciences, mathematics, and statistics) will be directly involved in all aspects of the research. They will get hands-on experience in neuroscientific studies and in using computers for data analysis and modeling. All teaching and scientific methods developed will be made publicly available and contributions disseminated in meetings, publications and on the lab web site.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research: We have explored the individual cells and circuits that make up the brain clock, and how it influences behavior. The principles of organization of the brain's SCN clock are likely to be generalizable to other brain regions.

We studied how individual neurons work together to form neuronal assemblies which then produce complex brain functions that are organized on a daily timetable. The circadian (daily) timing system is well positioned to explore network organization in the brain. This is because in this system, responses can be experimentally examined at multiple levels, from genes to cells, to tissues to whole animal behavior. While such studies at multiple levels of analysis are always the goal of research, they are not often available.

Daily oscillations of the molecular clock in individual cells are well known (Nobel Prize 2017). Tools for monitoring clock gene expression using reporter gene technology have enabled us to observe long-term changes in gene expression in cells and circuits. The data generated by such long-term recordings of the activity of hundreds or thousands of cells was analyzed with the tremendous computer power available. These features make the circadian system ideal for exploring the complex properties that emerge from the organization of neurons into networks.

We used a bioluminescent protein tagged to PERIOD2, a protein that is a key molecular component of the 24-hour clock in each neuron. Whenever PERIOD2 was produced, LUC was detected by our cameras. PERIOD2 expression oscillates across a 24-hour cycle, reaching a peak at about the time of dark onset.  By observing both the time and location of bioluminescence within SCN cells, we could observe the daily increases and decreases in the expression of the PERIOD2 clock protein. Before the availability of these tools, it had been assumed that all SCN neurons were coupled to each other and were completely synchronized. Instead of all cells working to produce a single coherent oscillation each day, we have shown that the SCN has a heterogeneous population of cells, and there is phase dispersion among oscillators. Small clusters of neurons are synchronized to each other, but all 20,000 neurons are not actually in synchrony with each other. Instead, small groups turn on and off serially, in a regular, repeated, daily sequence.

We next manipulated specific properties of these clock neurons and explored their anatomical connections and dynamic organization. To do this, we examined wild-type (normal) animals and mutant animals bearing various fundamentally different mutations that disrupt rhythmicity. In some, individual clock cells fail to oscillate, in others individual neurons oscillate, but connections among them are "broken." This research shows the different ways in which specific mutations can produce disruption of brain networks and alter behavior. In summary, by virtue of its unique access to information from the environment, the wiring among its individual components cells, and its signals to the rest of the brain, the tiny 20,000 neurons of SCN clock provide temporal organization to the entire body.

What is the impact of such work? In general, it is difficult to examine simultaneously, changes in time within individual cells, networks of cells, and the behavior that results from this activity. Knowledge of these coordinated changes is essential to understand how the brain works, and is the contribution of this research.

Broader Impacts: A major goal of this grant was to support and stimulate undergraduate women to incorporate programming education into their research and academic work. We have substantial experience in engaging students productively in this work. Since beginning this project, many individuals (~5/6 each semester) have been mentored directly in our lab. Many others have received further coding training through the Athena Digital Design Agency (ADDA) at Barnard College of Columbia University, which the PI helped found. Additionally, work on this project made the PI aware that women, including Barnard students, needed computational tools for this work and for most academic disciplines. The PI and her students played a major role in advocating for the creation of a new Computer Science Department at Barnard that was launched in January 2019. Collectively, these opportunities provided students with the tools, resources, experience, mentors, and passion to support the next generation of women in STEM.
